Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208,.proposition: This court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 208, Section 28, governing modifications of custody orders.

Mason v. Coleman, 478 Mass. 351 (2018).proposition: Since the inception of the custody order, the Plaintiff asserts a material change in circumstances warranting modification of the existing custody arrangement.

Bower v. O'Brien, 455 Mass. 155 (2009).proposition: Since the inception of the custody order, the Plaintiff asserts a material change in circumstances warranting modification of the existing custody arrangement.
Bower v. O'Brien, 455 Mass. 155 (2009).support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about murder, robbery, suppression motions, and joint venture felony-murder. It does not involve family law, custody orders, or standards for modification based on a material change in circumstances. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that a material change in circumstances since inception of a custody order warrants modification of custody.

Wilkinson v. Wilkinson, 440 Mass. 64 (20.proposition: Since the inception of the custody order, the Plaintiff asserts a material change in circumstances warranting modification of the existing custody arrangement.
Wilkinson v. Wilkinson, 440 Mass. 64 (20.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a criminal case about a motion to suppress evidence from a cocaine-trafficking investigation; it does not address family law, custody orders, or standards for modification based on a material change in circumstances. Nothing in the decision discusses custody arrangements or post-judgment modification standards. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a material change in circumstances since a custody order warrants modification of custody.
Wilkinson v. Wilkinson, 440 Mass. 64 (20.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals from his conviction of trafficking in cocaine, contending that his motion to suppress evidence was erroneously denied. … The defendant moved to suppress evidence of the cocaine found in his backpack on the ground that the officers had illegally searched the backpack and slit open the cocaine packaging. … The judge ruled that the opening of the backpack would be justified as a limited search for weapons.

Johnson v. Johnson, 422 Mass. 445 (1996).proposition: Since the inception of the custody order, the Plaintiff asserts a material change in circumstances warranting modification of the existing custody arrangement.
Johnson v. Johnson, 422 Mass. 445 (1996).support_reasoning: The case is an interjurisdictional custody jurisdiction decision under the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, not a modification-of-custody case based on a material change in circumstances. The opinion addresses whether Massachusetts has subject matter jurisdiction at all, and ultimately holds that Texas is the proper forum; it does not discuss or apply the legal standard for modifying an existing custody order due to a material change in circumstances. Therefore it does not support the proposition claimed.
Johnson v. Johnson, 422 Mass. 445 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “To determine whether the judge’s exercise of jurisdiction was proper, we look to the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (MCCJA). See G. L. c. 209B. ‘The decision of a Massachusetts court to exercise jurisdiction and to make a custody determination must be based solely on G. L. c. 209B.’ … We conclude that Massachusetts courts lack subject matter jurisdiction over the custody of Zeke and must defer to the Texas courts.”

Doe v. Doe, 410 Mass. 775 (1991).proposition: Since the inception of the custody order, the Plaintiff asserts a material change in circumstances warranting modification of the existing custody arrangement.
Doe v. Doe, 410 Mass. 775 (1991).case_name: Acme Laundry Co. v. Secretary of Environmental Affairs
Doe v. Doe, 410 Mass. 775 (1991).support_reasoning: The provided opinion is Acme Laundry Co. v. Secretary of Environmental Affairs, an environmental lien and hazardous materials cleanup case, not Doe v. Doe and not a custody or domestic relations decision. It does not discuss custody orders, material changes in circumstances, or standards for modifying custody. Therefore it cannot support the proposition that a material change in circumstances since a custody order warrants modification of custody.
Doe v. Doe, 410 Mass. 775 (1991).relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs state that the gravamen of their claim is that the DEQE could not place a lien on their property pursuant to the Massachusetts Oil and Hazardous Material Release Prevention Act, G.L.c. 21E, "because the DEQE has incurred no costs for the `assessment, containment, and removal'" of hazardous materials. Therefore, we look to the statute to determine how the Legislature defined "assessment" costs and when such costs can be the basis for a lien.

Adams v. Adams, 376 Mass. 149 (1978).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a criminal conviction for burning a motor vehicle and addresses evidentiary issues and the standard for a directed verdict in a criminal case. It does not discuss child custody, modification of custody orders, or the standard of “material change in circumstances” for modifying custody. Therefore, it provides no support or authority for the claimed custody-related proposition.
Adams v. Adams, 376 Mass. 149 (1978).relevant_excerpt: "The defendant was convicted by a jury of six of wilfully and maliciously burning a motor vehicle (G. L. c. 266, § 5) belonging to his mother. Before us, he challenges the admissibility of certain evidence and the denial of his motion for a directed verdict presented at the close of the Commonwealth’s case."
